Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Cluster algebras, combinatorics and representation theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project focuses on cluster algebras and their relation to the representation theory of finite-dimensional algebras and combinatorics. Cluster algebras are commutative algebras with a special combinatorial structure, which are related to various fields in mathematics and physics. The PI will pursue several investigations. For general cluster algebras, he plans to prove the positivity conjecture, which is the oldest unsolved conjecture in the field. For cluster algebras of surface type, the PI will study the properties of canonical bases introduced by him and his collaborators. Moreover, he will use the bases to gain a better understanding of the cluster algebra itself as well as its relationship with representation theory and Teichmueller theory. The Pi will also study automorphisms of cluster algebras which will lead to a better comprehension of the intrinsic symmetries of cluster algebras. The PI will integrate education and research at several levels. He will organize a graduate summer school on cluster algebras at the University of Connecticut. The PI will continue to develop an international network at institutions in Argentina, Canada and the US, which will allow advanced graduate students and postdocs to go abroad for two-week long research visits in order to exchange ideas with local researchers. Moreover, the PI will continue to run the cluster algebra seminar in his department.

When cluster algebras were introduced by Fomin and Zelevinsky in 2002, their original motivation came from representation theory, which is a branch of modern algebra. Studying the symmetries of a model is often more fruitful than studying the model directly, and representation theory has found many applications in physics and chemistry as well as in other mathematical fields. The cluster algebras provide a mathematical framework for fundamental patterns which occur throughout representation theory. Surprisingly, these patterns are also observed in various other branches of science which, a priori, are not related to representation theory. This motivates a further development of the theory of cluster algebras to which this project will contribute.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focuses on cluster algebras and their relation to representation theory and Teichmuller theory. Cluster algebras are commutative algebras with a special combinatorial structure and are related to various fields in mathematics and physics. A cluster algebra is generated by its cluster variables, which are Laurent polynomials in several variables that are constructed by a recursive method called mutation.

Intellectual Merit.

The first major result of the of the award is the proof of the positivity conjecture for cluster algebras [Lee-Schiffler 2015]. The positivity conjecture, formulated by Fomin and Zelevinsky in 2002 in the very first paper on cluster algebras, was the oldest unsolved conjecture in the field at the time. It states that the coefficients in the Laurent expansion of all cluster variables are positive. Although easily stated, it took 13 years before it was proved. 

A second major result of the award is the discovery of a direct relation between cluster algebras and continued fractions [Canakci-Schiffler 2018]. A continued fraction is a classical mathematical concept that is ubiquitous throughout mathematics. The authors give a combinatorial realization of continued fractions as quotients of cardinalities of sets, using the so-called snake graphs that were fundamental in earlier work by the PI. This led to a realization of the continued fraction as a specialization of a cluster variable in an associated cluster algebra. Completing the circle, this then gave a formula for the non-specialized cluster variable as a continued fraction of Laurent polynomials.This result is the culmination of a series of papers [Canakci-Schiffler [2013,15,17,18] in which the authors completed a systematic study of snake graphs and the closely related band graphs.

Another important aspect of the award is the development of the representation theory of cluster-tilted algebras. In a sequence of papers [Schiffler-Serhiyenko 2017-2018] and [Assem-Schiffler-Serhiyenko 2018], the induction of modules from tilted to cluster-tilted algebras was developed and applied to answer open questions in the theory.

As part of the project, the concept of unistructurality was introduced [Assem-Schiffler-Shramchenko 2014]. A cluster algebra is called unistructural if the set of cluster variables determines the combinatorial structure of the cluster algebra. The authors conjectured in 2014 that every cluster algebra is unistructural. This conjecture was solved in 2018 in a series of papers by Cao and Li. 

Lastly, let us mention that another important open question has been settled, namely the extension of the canonical basis to cluster algebras from surfaces with a single marked point on the boundary [Canakci-Lee-Schiffler 2015].


Broader Impacts.

A major component of the award consists in a number of educational activities. The Cluster Algebra Spring School at UConn in May 2017 was a weeklong school for PhD students consisting of four lecture series on the following topics, Continuous Cluster Categories by Gordana Todorov, Cluster Categories by Charles Paquette, Upper Cluster Algebras, Maximal Green Sequences and Greedy Bases by Kyungyong Lee, and Cluster Algebras of Surface Type and Continued Fractions by Ralf Schiffler. There were 32 students participating in the school. 


The award was also used to support graduate student exchanges. Students from UConn went for one or two weeks to another institution and students from other institutions spent a week at UConn in order to present their results, discuss with local researchers and build professional connections. The following UConn students participated in this project. Khrystyna Serhiyenko visited University of Sherbrooke, Canada, and Michelle Rabideau visited the LACIM at Universite du Quebec a Montreal. The following students came to visit UConn. Hipolito Treffinger from Sherbrooke, Emine Yildirim from UQAM Montreal, and Min Huang from Sherbrooke. 


The PI (co)-organized the following conferences, thematic programs and seminars. The Special Semester on Representation Theory at UConn Fall 2014, Special Program on Cluster Algebras at KIAS, Seoul, Nov.-Dec. 2014, International Conference on Representation Theory and Commutative Algebra, UConn 2015, International Conference on Representations of Algebras ICRA, Syracuse 2016, Special Sessions at the Mathematical Congress of the Americas, Montreal 2016, and AMS sectional meeting, Hartford 2019, and the Cluster Algebra Seminar at UConn. He also served on the scientific committees of the 52nd Spring Topology and Dynamical Systems Conference, Auburn, 2018 and the International Conference on Representations of Algebras ICRA, 2020.


The PI supervised the postdocs Charles Paquette and Emily Gunawan, and the graduates students Khrystyna Serhiyenko, Stephen Zito, Ana Garcia Elsener, Michelle Rabideau, Damian Wesenberg, Bing Duan and Paul Appruzese.
